paper_authors: Amiot, C. E.; El Hajj Boutros, G.; Sukhanova, K.; Karelis, A. D.
paper_title: Testing a novel multicomponent intervention to reduce meat consumption in young men
intervention_mechanism: factual, negative emotional, perspective taking, goal pursuit, norms

interventions.intervention_description: Participants received a presentation on declining meat consumption trends in Canada since 1980 and the negative health, animal welfare, and environmental impacts of meat consumption (including PETA videos). They completed a mind attribution task writing about a cow's thoughts and feelings, received practical tips for planning meat-free meals and making substitutions, and set a monthly goal to reduce, maintain, or increase their meat consumption. Text messages provided ongoing reinforcement with educational information, benefit reminders, and recipe links., Text-messaging reinforcement of the informational and self-monitoring components. The messages sent upbeat and educational information that reminded participants of the benefits of reducing meat consumption and provided them with additional tips and links to recipes.

outcomes.outcome_description: Total meat consumption over two weekdays and one weekend day

paper_authors: Mathur, M. B.; Peacock, J. R.; Robinson, T. N.; Gardner, C. D.
paper_title: Effectiveness of a theory-informed documentary to reduce consumption of meat and animal products: Three randomized controlled experiments
intervention_mechanism: factual, negative emotional, norms, origin of animal product, goal pursuit

interventions.intervention_description: Participants watched a 20-min documentary entitled "Good For Us", which encourages plant-based diets that reduce consumption of all meats and animal products. Each segment was followed by free-response questions about the content presented. After the documentary, participants were asked whether they would like to pledge to reduce their consumption, pledge to eliminate their consumption, or to make no pledge. For participants who had chosen to make at least one “reduce” or “eliminate” pledge, several items designed to improve general and specific goal-setting and self-monitoring were presented. One week after the baseline measurement, a customized reminder email was sent to pledge-making participants.

outcomes.outcome_description: Total weight of animal product consumption over the past week

paper_authors: Dakin, B. C.; Ching, A. E.; Teperman, E.; Klebl, C.; Moshel, M.; Bastian, B.
paper_title: Prescribing vegetarian or flexitarian diets leads to sustained reduction in meat intake

interventions.intervention_description: Participants read: "One type of diet that some people endorse is a Climatarian diet significantly reducing or eliminating red meat from one's diet. The reasoning is as follows: Livestock agriculture contributes up to a quarter of global greenhouse gas emissions, with almost all of this coming from cows and sheep. In Australia, producing 1 kg of beef requires an average of 15,182 L of water. Furthermore, livestock agriculture drives 80% of deforestation worldwide, using up a third of the world s ice-free land. Adopting a Climatarian diet is a powerfulway to reduce your impact on the climate. Shifting to a Climatarian diet will reduce your carbon footprint by approximately 1000 kg of CO2 every year, or the equivalent of driving from Perth to Brisbane."

outcomes.outcome_description: Total servings of 10 common meat types over the past seven days

paper_authors: Dakin, B. C.; Ching, A. E.; Teperman, E.; Klebl, C.; Moshel, M.; Bastian, B.
paper_title: Prescribing vegetarian or flexitarian diets leads to sustained reduction in meat intake

interventions.intervention_description: Participants read: "One type of diet that some people endorse is the ‘One step for the animals diet' eliminating chicken from our diets. The reasoning is as follows: Despite having the same capacity to suffer, farmed animals are denied the protection of animal cruelty laws that protect dogs and cats. This means that it is legal and widespread to cause immense suffering to animals raised for food. This includes painful surgical mutilations (without pain relief) and in most cases, intensive and unnatural overcrowding or confinement, and often a painful and traumatic slaughter. There are over 500 million animals confined like this in factory farms in Australia today. The vast majorityof these animals today are birds. It takes more than 200 chickens to provide the same number of meals as one cow.If we can convince someone to stop eating birds, they would go from being responsible for the factory farming and slaughtering of more than two dozen land animals per year to fewer than one. Furthermore, while most cows and sheep raised in Australia spend most of their life grazing, the vast majority of chickens are raised in crowded factory farms."

Participants read: "One type of diet that some people endorse is a Reducetarian diet reducing the amount of meat that we eat. The reasoning is as follows: Despite having the same capacity to suffer, farmed animals are denied the protection of animal cruelty laws that protect dogs and cats. This means that it is legal and widespread to cause immense suffering to animals raised for food. This includes painful surgical mutilations (without pain relief) and in most cases, intensive and unnatural overcrowding or confinement, and often a painful and traumatic slaughter. There are over 500 million animals confined like this in factoryfarms in Australia today. This includes cows, pigs, sheep and chickens. Adopting a reductionist diet is appealing because not everyone is willing to follow an all-or-nothing diet. It is also a powerful way to reduce animal cruelty. For example, halving your meat consumption will spare around 50 innocent lives every year. This includes about 13 land animals, and 37 fish and shellfish every year."

Participants read:  "One type of diet that some people endorse is a Vegetarian diet eliminating all meat and fish from one's diet. The reasoning is as follows: Despite having the same capacity to suffer, farmed animals are denied the protection of animal cruelty laws that protect dogs and cats. This means that it is legal and widespread to cause immense suffering to animals raised for food. This includes painful surgical mutilations (without pain relief) and in most cases, intensive and unnatural overcrowding or confinement, and often a painful and traumatic slaughter. There are over 500 million animals confined like this in factory farms in Australia today. This includes cows, pigs, sheep and chickens. Adopting a vegetarian diet is the most powerful way to object to animal cruelty, and by doing so, you will spare approximately 100 animal lives (25 land animals and 75 fish and shellfish) every year."

outcomes.outcome_description: Total servings of 10 common meat types over the past seven days

paper_authors: Pohlmann, A.
paper_title: The taste of compassion: Influencing meat attitudes with interhuman and interspecies moral appeals

interventions.intervention_description: With a visible timer counting down from 3 min, participants were asked to recall 10 behaviors where they acted “particularly masculine/manly” or “particularly feminine/womanly” (depending on their gender). Participants read that men and women can easily recall 12 behaviors. The task is intentionally difficult with the purpose of leading participants to infer that their performance is below purportedly acceptable standards for their respective gender, thus threatening gender identity. Then, participants were asked to evaluate photographic art prints that a restaurant is considering exhibiting in its dining areas: participants viewed a slideshow consisting of 15 pretested stock photographs portraying scenes of vulnerability, human connection, care-giving, and displays of emotional distress. The photos pictured female and male adults, as well as children and the elderly, and a range of ethnicities.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of participants selecting a meat entrée out of ten pairs of photographs of popular entrées that can be prepared with meat or in a vegetarian version

interventions.intervention_description: Installation of of visual manipulations under the guise of a photo exhibit at the restaurant. outcomes.outcome_description: Number of meat menu item sales

interventions.intervention_description: All participants completed an essay task that threatened gender identity and subsequently watched a slideshow. paper_authors: Karakaş, N., Jaeger, B.
paper_title: Changes in attitudes toward meat consumption after chatting with a large language model

interventions.intervention_description: Participants had an open-ended chat about meat consumption that lasted 5-10 minutes with ChatGPTT-4o. The same initial prompt was entered for all participants: “I want to have a conversation about meat consumption. I currently eat meat. Are there any reasons why I should limit my meat consumption or stop eating meat entirely?”. Participants were given a list of questions they could ask ChatGPT, but were also told that they could decide where to steer the conversation. The provided questions focused on the environment (e.g., “How does meat consumption impact the environment?”), personal health (e.g., “Is it necessary to eat meat to be healthy?”), and animal welfare (e.g., “What percentage of meat in Dutch supermarkets comes from factory farms?”), and also included more generic prompts (e.g., “It would be quite difficult to reduce my meat consumption by a lot. How can I make this easier?”).

outcomes.outcome_description: Average score on the Meat Commitment Scale

Participants were asked a multiple-choice question regarding whether they try to cut back on the amount of meat they eat. They could select from the following options: (a) Yes, I am actively trying to cut back; (b) No, but I have cut back on meat in the past; (c) No, but I am considering cutting back; (d) No, I am not considering cutting back (skip to question 6B); (e) I do not eat meat; (f) I'm not sure. The outcome represents the percentage of participants trying to cut back on their meat consumption.

Please indicate which type of voucher you would like to receive if you win."

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of participants choosing the voucher for a meat sandwich

paper_authors: Dannenberg, A.; Weingärtner, E.
paper_title: The effects of observability and an information nudge on food choice

For example, food-related greenhouse gas emissions can on average be lowered by about a quarter (24%) through following a vegetarian diet and by about half (53%) through following a vegan diet." before their choice of voucher was publicly announced

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of participants choosing the voucher for a meat sandwich

paper_authors: Weikertova, S.; Urban, J.

interventions.intervention_description: Participants received dynamic norm treatment as they were provided information about decreasing meat consumption in non-specific reference groups, and about an increasing demand for vegetarian meals in the specific reference group.

outcomes.outcome_description: Participants' choice of meatless meals in a choice experiment task including one meat-based and one meatless meal. These meals adapted from university canteens, not labeled,as vegetarian or not, and they had a fixed price.

paper_authors: Schwantes, C.
paper_title: The meat of the matter: Using social marketing to influence red meat purchase behaviour

interventions.intervention_description: Customers entering the intervention store were asked the following question: “To consider a healthy and sustainable lifestyle, would you be interested in reducing your red meat purchases by one meal per week?” If customers agreed, they were asked to demonstrate their commitment by having their name listed on the public-facing project website, www.meatofthematerstudy.squarespace.com. They were also given a small business card with the project website to see their name and learn more about the study.

outcomes.outcome_description: Amount of red meat purchased at the grocery store on average

Participants read foodprint information, but the same numerical information was scaled to the individual level and adjusted for a single individual, e.g. “A single beef burger, for example, has a water footprint of approximately 450 gallons of water. To put this in perspective, 450 gallons is more than what an average person drinks in two years.”

paper_authors: Lohmann, P. M.; Gsottbauerb, E.; Farringtone, J.; Human, S.; Reisch, L. A.
paper_title: Choice architecture promotes sustainable choices in online food-delivery apps

interventions.intervention_description: Participants were presented with a simulated delivery platform, with an additional tax imposed on items containing meat. The menu page of a respective item displayed a red “T” icon and the text “Includes £X.XX of meat tax.” In the selection pop-up and in the checkout basket, an extra row identified the price added by the tax as “+£X.XX meat tax.” Additional rows displayed a small information icon, providing further details about the tax’s purpose and impact (“An additional meat tax has been added to this item to reflect its climate impact”) if hovered over with the mouse or touched on a mobile device.

outcomes.outcome_description: Proportion of meat or fish mains chosen

paper_authors: Lohmann, P. M.; Gsottbauerb, E.; Farringtone, J.; Human, S.; Reisch, L. A.
paper_title: Choice architecture promotes sustainable choices in online food-delivery apps

interventions.intervention_description: Participants were presented with a simulated delivery platform, with additional information in the form of carbon-footprint labels included on the menu page of every food item and selection pop-up. Meal items are rated based on their carbon footprint per kilogram using categories from A (very low) to E (very high), following the Global Carbon Budget for Food (2019 EAT-Lancet Commission).

outcomes.outcome_description: Proportion of meat or fish mains chosen

paper_authors: Lohmann, P. M.; Gsottbauerb, E.; Farringtone, J.; Human, S.; Reisch, L. A.
paper_title: Choice architecture promotes sustainable choices in online food-delivery apps

interventions.intervention_description: The simulated delivery platform design that participants were presented with was altered to emphasize low-carbon alternatives. Both the restaurant and menu pages were re-ordered, presenting options in decreasing order of sustainability, i.e., the lowest-carbon restaurants and meal items (within each menu category) were presented first.

outcomes.outcome_description: Proportion of meat or fish mains chosen

interventions.intervention_description: Participants received 2–3 environment-focused SMS per week for eight consecutive weeks via Textedly. interventions.intervention_description: Participants received the Educa­ted Choices Program’s (ECP) The Planet and Our Plates presentation, which describes the environmental impacts of animal agriculture versus plant-based food choices. interventions.intervention_description: Participants participated in a 6-week cooking class in which they observed the preparation of a plant-based, olive oil diet meal and got to taste test; While the recipe was being prepared, the staff discussed consistent themes each week, including the health benefits of extra virgin olive oil and encouraging the participants to use olive oil to cook their vegetables; meat/poultry/seafood is not needed daily; vegetables and all starch products (including beans) contain protein. No other nutrition- or food-related information was provided. All of the recipes were made with extra virgin olive oil (1 to 2 tablespoons), contained on average 2 servings of vegetables, and did not contain meat/poultry or seafood

paper_title: Estimating the effect of moving meat-free products to the meat aisle on sales of meat and meat-free products: A non-randomised controlled intervention study in a large UK supermarket chain

interventions.intervention_description: The intervention consisted of moving 26 uniquely barcoded meat-free products within 4 meat-free categories (50% sausages, 30% burgers, 12% meatballs, and 8% mince) from their usual section into a newly created meat-free bay within the meat aisle. This new bay of meatfree products covered the whole bay, including top, middle, and bottom shelves. This meatfree section replaced a bay where either meat was previously sold (16 stores) or where the bay previously contained chilled condiments (3 stores) or was unused (1 store)

outcomes.outcome_description: changes in (units/items sold) per store per week for intervention and control conditions

paper_title: Nudge interventions to reduce fish sauce consumption in Thailand

interventions.intervention_description: After buying their noodles, consumers can add fish sauce. The fish sauce serving container was changed to a bowl (with 500g of fish sauce) with a “regular spoon” (that can extract 15g of fish sauce), instead of being served in the 750ml bottle

outcomes.outcome_description: Amount of fish sauce used (in grams) out of the number of bowls sold

paper_authors: Kanchanachitra, M.; Chamchan, C.; Kanchanachitra, C.; Suttikasem, K.; Gunn, L. H.; Vlaev, I.
paper_title: Nudge interventions to reduce fish sauce consumption in Thailand

interventions.intervention_description: After buying their noodles, consumers can add fish sauce. The fish sauce serving container was changed to a bowl (with 500g of fish sauce) with a “special spoon” (that can hold 3.3g of fish sauce), instead of being served in the 750ml bottle. The special spoon, named the “less spoon”, has a hole in the middle and can extract 3.3 g of fish sauce at a time, or approximately two thirds of a teaspoon. Displayed near the bowl of fish sauce was an A4-sized information sheet introducing the “less spoon” with the short message: “Do not add more than 2/3 teaspoons of fish sauce per meal”.

outcomes.outcome_description: Amount of fish sauce used (in grams) out of the number of bowls sold

paper_authors: Kanchanachitra, M.; Chamchan, C.; Kanchanachitra, C.; Suttikasem, K.; Gunn, L. H.; Vlaev, I.
paper_title: Nudge interventions to reduce fish sauce consumption in Thailand

interventions.intervention_description: After buying their noodles, consumers can add fish sauce. The fish sauce was served in a bottle, but an A4-sized information sheet was also displayed near the fish sauce bottle. The sheet provided information regarding the amount of sodium already in noodles and the recommended sodium consumption per meal. The information sheet also showed a picture of a smartwatch with a healthy heart, a 120/80 blood pressure reading, a positive reinforcement message “GREAT JOB”, and a short message reading: “Less salty, reduces disease, weight, and bloating”.

outcomes.outcome_description: Amount of fish sauce used (in grams) out of the number of bowls sold

paper_authors: Kanchanachitra, M.; Chamchan, C.; Kanchanachitra, C.; Suttikasem, K.; Gunn, L. H.; Vlaev, I.
paper_title: Nudge interventions to reduce fish sauce consumption in Thailand

interventions.intervention_description: After buying their noodles, consumers can add fish sauce. The fish sauce was served in a bottle, but an A4-sized information sheet with an affective-provoking picture was also displayed nearby the fish sauce bottle. The sheet provided information regarding the amount of sodium already in noodles and the recommended sodium consumption per meal. In addition, there was a picture of a girl making a disgusted face with a short message saying “too salty”.

outcomes.outcome_description: Amount of fish sauce used (in grams) out of the number of bowls sold

paper_authors: Marty, L.; Biehlmann, M.; Louveau, A.; Poquet, D.; Robinson, E.
paper_title: The “Eat Less Meat” one-month challenge: a randomized controlled trial of a meat reduction pledge intervention among French university students

interventions.intervention_description: Participants received by email a cookbook of ten easy-to-prepare and cheap meat-free recipes and a starter kit with advice and motivational tips. For a month, they received an email each week (four in total) with more advice and motivational tips. They were also asked to follow the Instagram account of the “Eat less meat” one-month challenge, where during one month, one publication was posted every day except on Sundays, engaging stories requiring interactions were posted regularly, participants could ask their questions to the research team, and participants could communicate. The online materials targeted both reflective motivation (directly) by attempting to enhance health, environment and animal welfare concerns and automatic motivation (indirectly through capability and opportunity) by attempting to alleviate barriers to reduce meat consumption and thus increasing participants’ commitment to the challenge.

outcomes.outcome_description: Daily meat intake in grams (i.e., beef patties, beef, pork, veal, lamb, poultry, liver, other offal, salami, mortadella, ham and sausages)

paper_authors: Abrahamse, W.; Steg, L.; Vlek, C.; Rothengatter, T.
paper_title: The effect of tailored information, goal setting, and tailored feedback on household energy use, energy-related behaviors, and behavioral antecedents

interventions.intervention_description: Two groups of households received tailored energy-saving information, including details about global warming and energy costs, plus a personalized list of relevant energy-saving measures. Both groups were asked to achieve a 5% energy reduction and received individual feedback via a website showing their percentage energy savings, the contribution of each behavior, and money saved. The first group received only individual goals and feedback, while the second group also received a collective 5% group goal and monthly feedback about the group's average and total energy savings via newsletter.

outcomes.outcome_description: Meat consumption per meal

paper_authors: Acharya, S.; Maskarinec, G.; Williams, A. E.; Oshiro, C.; Hebshi, S.; Murphy, P.
paper_title: Nutritional changes among premenopausal women undertaking a soya based dietary intervention study in Hawaii

interventions.intervention_description: Regular supplies of soy foods were given free-of-charge to the intervention group. Based on individual preferences, the study dietitian made speciﬁc suggestions on how to incorporate soy foods into the daily menu, such as replacing meat with tofu in stew or fried dishes, cow milk with soyamilk, and cookies with a soya protein bar. To avoid weight gain, replacing other foods was emphasized over adding soya foods. To maintain compliance, all participants received individual dietary counselling by a registered dietitian and follow-up phone calls. They had at least six contacts with the dietitian during the ﬁrst year and were counselled on how to maintain a healthy diet according to the food guide pyramid.

outcomes.outcome_description: Total dairy servings consumed during the previous day
Milk servings consumed during the previous day
Yoghurt servings consumed during the previous day
Cheese servings consumed during the previous day
Meat, poultry, and fish servings consumed during the previous day

Eggs servings consumed during the previous day

paper_authors: Aldoh, A.; Sparks, P.; Harris, P. R.
paper_title: Dynamic norms and food choice: Reflections on a failure of minority norm information to influence motivation to reduce meat consumption

interventions.intervention_description: Participants read a norm statement depicting a dynamic norm regarding meat consumption in the UK: "Recent research has shown that, in the last 5 years, 30% of people in the UK have now started to make an effort to limit their meat consumption. That means that, in recent years, 3 in 10 people in the UK have begun to eat less meat than they otherwise would. Why do you think this is?"

Participants read a norm statement depicting a static norm regarding meat consumption in the UK: "Recent research has shown that 30% of people in the UK make an effort to limit their meat consumption. That means that 3 in 10 people in the UK eat less meat than they otherwise would. Why do you think this is?"

outcomes.outcome_description: Interest in reducing meat consumption (i.e. “How interested are you in eating less meat?”)
Expectations to reduce meat consumption (i.e. “I am going to reduce my meat consumption from now on”)
Attitude towards meat reduction
Intention to reduce meat consumption within the next year

paper_title: Evidence on the effectiveness-acceptance trade-off between forced active choice and default nudging: A field study to reduce meat consumption in cafeterias

interventions.intervention_description: Cafeteria users who selected a meat dish were informed that they had the option to choose the same dish with either a small or large meat content, with all other ingredients being adjustable in size. Users were then prompted to make their meal configuration choices. Additionally, signs were placed in the serving area and at the entrance of the dining hall to explain the reduced option. This sign also highlighted with specific numbers how much more people could be nourished if agricultural land were used for bread production instead of pork production.

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of participants choosing the reduced meat portion for their meal

paper_authors: Lemken, D.; Simonetti, A.; Sindermann, G.; Magnasco, A. I. E.
paper_title: Evidence on the effectiveness-acceptance trade-off between forced active choice and default nudging: A field study to reduce meat consumption in cafeterias

interventions.intervention_description: The dish with the reduced meat portion was set as the meat default choice. Consequently, if cafeteria users did not explicitly request the regular meat portion size, they would automatically receive the dish with the smaller meat portion. Signs were placed everywhere that cafeteria users are free to adjust their meat components

outcomes.outcome_description: Percentage of participants choosing the reduced meat portion for their meal
